title: Cognitive Development – Approaches to Learning: Birth-5
subject: Early Learning Standards (2016-)

943862BE2D734A08A15D30A2446F7FDA.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds:  Understand that symbols on pictographs and bar graphs indicate quantity
(E.g. Chethan puts a sticker on the class graph to show that he has a cat at
home and remarks, “More children have a dog at home than a cat.”)

3B1AAE75906F4D559B8EE66407C50DBF.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds:  Use objects to represent other objects in their pretend play (E.g. Hadley and
Kayla build an elaborate castle using couch cushions and blankets.)

EF86ED4D0CA04B80B0B0BD77155A244D.description:
Three Years: Are aware that some symbols
represent words and numbers

F4EB0BC50E714A86A83F7CFF9E807D6C.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Understand that some signs
in the community represent
familiar places

AD0C69155BC84B23A05C761F3E21E567.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Use a variety of materials,
media, and other forms of selfexpression to represent their
thinking (E.g. Tessa makes up
songs about herself.)

48E74EF99589441EBDE9637AFC3D7F47.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Use an object to represent
something else

37A694F5CE184FF0BE0F2769C2D2B7CC.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: May draw comfort from objects
that represent family members
or primary caregivers (E.g. Bertti
keeps her mother’s scarf in her
cubby and clings to it when
upset.)

2F3EE673D0634A1296D4E1493B9A5423.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Calm in the presence of
their primary caregiver
(E.g. Gigi clings to her teacher
when a stranger enters the
classroom.)

65C1412BB6244D23BC1D71C6152176E9.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: May get frustrated if they cannot carry out their goals to the level of mastery
they desire

D5C5F59CA676489D9CFE43D403341353.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Take the initiative carrying out their own plans and persist until the goal is
achieved

E6011F9BA3854D6A954492F7ACF0906C.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Demonstrate a desire to please adults and may seek adult attention
(E.g. 4-year-old Zara yells “Watch me! Watch me!” as she walks across the
balance beam.)

D24E70968918491D80EA4597FA784A07.description:
Three Years: Show initiative in a variety of
ways including offering to help

4B0372A2AFA74FFC97562556347BA271.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Demonstrate the motivation to
master simple tasks

9D2EA5F1680145268D7D01E167B1B336.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Persist in following their own
curiosity even if adults try to
deter them (E.g. 24-month-old
Sebastian keeps dropping his
toy cars in the toilet bowl even
though his mother tells him
not to.)

E9AFC8A233FF45BA9FD61C25EA6F5706.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Initiate simple plans
(E.g. 20-month-old Abreeanna
pulls on her teacher’s hand
and says, “out”, as she walks
to the door.)

0760C4E3198042809EE0F31ABEBEDC70.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Explore objects that interest
them with focus and persistence

EA69BC14E2DA4D44B4274F4D670B6237.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Persist in pursuing objects
of interest (E.g. 9-monthold Jasper crawls after her
family’s cat.)

3150701C986F4F6CA9BAC529A2E60E47.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Stay focused for longer periods of time on activities that interest them and
return to those activities

AD3302C75BCB43A3B44CAE729C005933.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds:  Keep track of more than one thing at a time

7B4A9D303C914AD89063ABD1108435D1.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Pay attention to and remember details

142DB089BD4642CA8A92D478A866A40A.description:
Three Years: Can play simple memory
games such as matching
pictures on cards

F2F66EBF76174D4ABEC5D1415DF0DB29.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Can maintain attention on their
choice of activity until they have
achieved their goal (E.g. Cheng
draws one more line on her
picture and says, “All done.”)

B6F661847FA24840AF5586860E26E9A0.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Have increased attention spans
for activities that interest them
or that they initiate

583C21A5D85E448C813A1E2012CD5D37.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Stay focused on simple stories
or books for brief periods of time

DA9183E8D7DD4A1B8DAFCCDEB4CFE927.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Can have expectations of what
will happen based on previous
experiences (E.g. Wilfred pulls
his mother’s hand to bring her
to the refrigerator knowing she
will offer juice to him.)

A96E181B2F3E43B5991AD4CDBBF6E3C1.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Begin to maintain focus
despite distractions during
brief delays

3BF1AB3AA147475C94CD8A8A03F40238.description:
Working memory
and focus and
attention

61567ACE327248FB9CBA54A1ACA72829.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: May ask for help on own or with teacher prompting or seek more information
when needed

7240A3165B5A42AF960D4FE2BEE40D7D.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Can engage in increasingly complex planning (E.g. The 4-year-olds create very
complex rules for the game they are playing on the playground.)

C2FD6557011C41898E813EEB3720BB89.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Can adapt their plan to include other children with adult guidance

4E0095B50924481D861D48A0F483F4AA.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Begin to show ability to adapt their plans when they can’t follow through with
their original idea

5D7A6A3B7C934299BC931CE91225FED1.description:
Three Years: Can adapt plans to
incorporate new materials

E510AABCD0EC49AE91E803F25EFFB51F.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Plan their own simple activities
and organize the materials
they need

924BA511A6A24BF0A52F46FF52D442A5.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Can try to figure out what is
getting in the way of their plan

54D11598B6B04FC6B1857D56D1FF3D51.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Plan and implement a two-step
dramatic play (E.g. Ezra pretends
to feed the baby doll and then
puts it in the baby bed.)

A81ADB28AA204EE1B15B7F9686076747.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Can carry out their own onestep plan (E.g. Penthia puts a
hat on her head.)

8253D805D8794E368F0D34E2C479FEDA.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Can act intentionally to
achieve a goal (E.g. 8-monthold Oscar rolls across the floor
to reach a toy.)

B0D5756646134866A1EDE20C898BAC9A.description:
Adaptability
of thought
processes,
planning, and
intentionality

A82B32A0F17C48228B70BB01F92D0DEF.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Pretend to be characters from stories, books, television shows, movies, or their
own invention

62B472D6D4A54A2C9B695C17C70001C9.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds:  Create games that continue to evolve as they plan

D079892DF1EB470BAC68782C81306ECC.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Tell elaborate stories of their own invention or add details to stories

251C086C59614F988052159A60A94261.description:
Three Years: Laugh at themselves when
they do something silly

CE807E96284E41BBAEDB3816C1986B11.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Play exuberantly

FE451E7FAE8D485B83C191752726844B.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Are amused by incongruity
(E.g. Jonah laughs hysterically
when his father pretends to put
Jonah’s shoes on his big feet.)

280E53D9465644A49162D99F0702C970.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Take delight in repetitive games
and interactions (E.g. Bodhi and
his teacher pass a ball back and
forth and each time the teacher
pretends to stop, Bodhi says,
“again” and laughs when the
teacher starts again.)

F9AA682E8ADB4BE5BE37F005CFB18864.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Express delight in ways
appropriate to their culture

E96116CCE821418D8279A78430CF16C9.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Show pleasure in simple
sensory games (E.g. AJ’s
mother tugs at the blanket in
his hands and he tugs it back
toward himself. They do this
several times as AJ laughs.)

232C2D474A324778A38A93A5F956DF6D.description:
Sense of delight
and humor*
*delight and humor are
culturally influenced

36EB15984493482ABACAD13779FD563A.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: May share physical humor with one another

3FBCDCE2B45141CE840659EE58407933.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Begin to understand simple jokes

803D884289FD47C9ABE520FC76FA022C.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: May play with language including “bathroom” words

12C81A4A9F2740508AB38E3C35CB076E.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Show delight in all aspects of play from planning to describing the experience

8F5874CE6DCA41F194F5DA29784AFAB8.description: Three Years: Invent stories and characters

FD224BC006524B6A968137AB7892543D.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Engage in more extended
pretend play

DFAB28B7DE18476DAAB22679084CA593.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Begin to engage in simple
pretend games

5E350BDDD6E34D7B9BD5080762D066EC.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Play with toys in ways of their
own invention. (E.g. Kai puts
blocks and cars together in a
single structure.)

96EA1A1CF2354AA991002BBA0E41C994.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: May invent ways to attract adult
attention and engage with them
(E.g. Gretta pretends to cough
to gain her teacher’s attention
and repeats this when her
teacher laughs.)

E0BB99D82165489DA7EDB0911FBAE8F8.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Infants this young do not
demonstrate creativity,
imagination, and inventiveness
in ways that adults can easily
interpret

99F1910EA88F44C8BA40FE5432B2CF93.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Create sophisticated structures alone and with others, using various constructive
materials, sometimes used in pretend play

6C75B94A818D49D8AFA5CFA59C12926F.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Engage in pretend play with others to explore and understand life experience
and roles

9E5BFFAB180449AF868D747719699430.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Co-create elaborate pretend play with other children, including scenarios with
multiple roles, ideas, and co-negotiated rules

A696ED44EAB94159B99E01EAC9CC861A.description:
Three Years: Engage in pretend play
that includes roles and
experiences that they find
challenging (E.g. After a visit
to the doctor, Brett gives her
doll a shot.)

8528BD24D7AA41F0BAAF8B4D7063D169.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Take risks in big body play,
expanding their physical abilities

00F19F07A9E34BD290BF83E3033B8434.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Try out new actions, roles, and
words that they imitate from
others

F18928E041F74725BFA180A7992ECE55.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Enjoy using their whole bodies in
active play

0142AAD416494EF9A9CB5D532C7E336A.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: May initiate turn taking with
a trusted adult (E.g. Spencer
gives a small toy to his
grandmother and she gives
another toy to him. They repeat
this several times.)

E8B087F6B91444B7883048FD2EDA3BCC.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Engage in turn taking
interactions with adults and
explore a variety of materials
including their own bodies,
people, and objects

E3184CD51F5A4995952157F5E8011A1A.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Work with others to plan or problem solve toward a shared goal and can describe
the reasons for their shared decisions (E.g. Aaron, Chuck, and Jill make a
complex track for a train and discuss how sharp curves make trains derail.)

CAB232A734344D6EB8041827F2C2A57C.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Can figure out more than one solution to a problem if the first one doesn’t work
(E.g. In trying to get a ball down from the tree, Marlow first throws a shoe to
get it down and when that doesn’t work, gets a rake to try to poke it down.)

CCF48DBAE10345F1B2354BF05684418C.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Talk about own ideas, predictions, and plans, building on prior experiences
either self-initiated or guided by adults

5E2E4F24E69C46A1BC3E9EC171DE55E1.description:
Three Years: Remember strategies that
have worked and apply them
to new situations (E.g. At
home, Davis moves a stool
to the sink so that he can
reach for his toothbrush. At
child care the next day, Davis
struggles to reach a pencil on
the counter so he picks up
a chair and puts it near the
counter.)

753B492053F24101A1C557F412E91831.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Solve some problems without
having to physically try out all
possible solutions and may ask
for help when needed

25D7BAFE76E54895BD0B4BAE4AD5CDEC.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Use multiple strategies to solve
simple problems, but may
become frustrated when their
strategies don’t work

1D3C930ACE9C421FBA506B487E120DF6.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Process and assimilate new
information and experiences
by comparing them to previous
information and experiences to
expand their understanding of
the world (E.g. Margaret sees a
horse for the first time and says,
“Big doggie!”)

617C943DFB7C46AC808ACD5FCD9CFC7E.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Act out ideas about how things
work by repeating and changing
their actions (trial and error)

D93F231015CB4484BF4115B13E55E97E.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Seek to make sense of what
happens in their environment

D50827A1CDA14307B775740950164740.description:
Theories about
the world and how
things work
(Reflection,
critical thinking,
and trial and
error)

C05B77ED2F774153B1EFBC6C7F0E9138.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Engage in repeated actions to make something happen (E.g. Dannie notices
that Marie buttons her own coat, so Dannie tries several methods before
succeeding in buttoning her own coat.)

0E04DA2404E848F4995031B4852D4B05.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Continue to experiment with cause and effect

6C7C3930D8BC4298BAD67515994A97C3.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Sometimes use magical thinking, showing misunderstanding of cause and effect
(E.g. Zeke puts his snow pants by the front door, believing that this will make it
snow overnight.)

FA52EB34A6E440FD9F3B51AF720DF514.description:
Three Years: Use variations on previous
actions in new environments
and with different objects to
create new and desired effects

F0D855582A0D4E0EAD5C215D9B19C713.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Anticipate and try to prevent
another person’s actions that
will create undesirable effects

613FEDA6BB88430BA450B072699EDCCD.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Repeat actions to create the
same effect and add variations
of those actions to see if the
same thing happens

8AEEB12EBE03404F8AD092D0E86626E4.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Experiment with cause and
effect while investigating their
environment

0EFA0351CEA245ADB54E6668F8C5E4E9.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: May do things to get a response
from familiar adults and children
(E.g. Luke drops peas and looks
over to his caregiver as they fall
from the table to the floor.)

8A2E375B794B460E8A0F6632A4641F9B.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Understand that their actions
can have an effect on
people and objects in their
environment and repeat
actions to duplicate effects
(E.g. Colleen gently bounces
6-month-old Rory on her
lap. When she stops, Rory
moves his body up and down
until Colleen resumes the
bouncing.)

68C0EF6D3FE142669A920B77FE23B714.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Use senses and tools/technology to aid in investigation

21736490E2AD45D28435BE1AB15EEC64.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Observe, wonder, and/or ask questions, make guesses, and explore hypotheses

D3CA58ADE3A1483E9E528796726A6257.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Continue to seek information
through observation,
exploration, and asking
questions

2353D2CAF64D4A0BA01616ECF6EBD47D.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Seek information through
observation, exploration, and
use of simple tools (E.g. Arthur
pulls a chair up to the kitchen
counter to see what his father is
making for dinner.)

A26C431F0139466EB3454BEADA776C1F.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Continue to investigate people
and objects as tools

69AF980AA1254EA28346986BCF396939.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Explore objects using their
senses and manipulate them in
a variety of ways

EB3BD5E600A44C15A7C0A156750FAC55.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Show awareness of
occurrences in their
surroundings and use their
senses to explore people and
objects
